Several lines of evidence have previously been used to suggest that ice retreat after the last glacial maximum (LGM) resulted in regionally-increased levels of volcanic activity. It has been proposed that this increase in volcanism was globally significant, forming a substantial component of the post-glacial rise in atmospheric CO2, and thereby contributing to climatic warming. However, as yet there has been no detailed investigation of activity in glaciated volcanic arcs following the LGM. Arc volcanism accounts for 90% of present-day subaerial volcanic eruptions. It is therefore important to constrain the impact of deglaciation on arc volcanoes, to understand fully the nature and magnitude of global-scale relationships between volcanism and glaciation. The first part of this paper examines the post-glacial explosive eruption history of the Andean southern volcanic zone (SVZ), a typical arc system, with additional data from the Kamchatka and Cascade arcs. In all cases, eruption rates in the early post-glacial period do not exceed those at later times at a statistically significant level. In part, the recognition and quantification of what may be small (i.e. less than a factor of two) increases in eruption rate is hindered by the size of our datasets. These datasets are limited to eruptions larger than 0.1 km3, because deviations from power-law magnitude–frequency relationships indicate strong relative under-sampling at smaller eruption volumes. In the southern SVZ, where ice unloading was greatest, eruption frequency in the early post-glacial period is approximately twice that of the mid post-glacial period (although frequency increases again in the late post-glacial). A comparable pattern occurs in Kamchatka, but is not observed in the Cascade arc. The early post-glacial period also coincides with a small number of very large explosive eruptions from the most active volcanoes in the southern and central SVZ, consistent with enhanced ponding of magma during glaciation and release upon deglaciation. In comparison to non-arc settings, evidence of post-glacial increases in rates of arc volcanism is weak, and there is no need to invoke significantly increased melt production upon ice unloading, as occurred in areas such as Iceland. Non-arc volcanoes may therefore account for a relatively higher proportion of global volcanic emissions in the early post-glacial period than is suggested by the relative contributions of arc and non-arc settings at the present day. The second part of this paper critically examines global eruption records, in an effort to constrain global-scale changes in volcanic output since the LGM. Accurate interpretation of these records relies on correcting both temporal and spatial variability in eruption recording. In particular, very low recording rates, which also vary spatially by over two orders of magnitude, prevent precise, and possibly even accurate, quantitative analysis. For example, if we assume record completeness for the past century, the number of known eruptions (volcanic explosivity index ≥ 2) from some low-latitude regions, such as Indonesia, is approximately 1 in 20,000 (0.005%) for the period 5–20 ka. There is a need for more regional-scale studies of past volcanism in such regions, where current data are extremely sparse. We attempt to correct for recording biases, and suggest a maximum two-fold (but potentially much less) increase in global eruption rates, relative to the present day, between 13 and 7 ka. Although volcanism may have been an important source of CO2 in the early Holocene, it is unlikely to have been a dominant control on changes in atmospheric CO2 after the LGM.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A possible coupling between volcanism and glacial cycles has been discussed for many years (Grove, 1976; Rampino et al., 1979; Hall, 1982; Nakada and Yokose, 1992; Sigvaldason et al., 1992; McGuire et al., 1997; Capra, 2006; Bigg et al., 2008; Huybers and Langmuir, 2009; Narcisi et al., 2010; Kutterolf et al., 2013; Nyland et al., 2013). For example, after the last glacial maximum (LGM; ~26.5–19 ka), with deglaciation starting from ~19 to 14 ka (Clark et al., 2009; Denton et al., 2010), volcanic eruption rates in Iceland were several times higher than at present (Sigvaldason et al., 1992; Maclennan et al., 2002; Sinton et al., 2005). Similarly, eruption rates in continental Europe (Nowell et al., 2006) and eastern California (Glazner et al., 1999) show increases following deglaciation, over several glacial cycles. Such increases may be globally significant: Huybers and Langmuir (2009) used an analysis of global eruption records to conclude that volcanic activity increased by a factor of 2–6 globally, from 12 to 7 ka, due to enhanced eruption rates across formerly glaciated regions. Associated increases in volcanic emissions potentially contributed significantly to the post-glacial increase in atmospheric CO2. However, there has been no systematic regional-scale investigation of whether volcanism increased in glaciated volcanic arcs after the LGM (Iceland, continental Europe and eastern California are all non-arc settings). Arc volcanoes account for 90% of recorded subaerial eruptions since A.D. 1900 (Siebert and Simkin, 2002-), and it is therefore important to interpret the response of glaciated volcanic arcs to ice retreat, in order to quantify the impact of deglaciation on global volcanic fluxes.
The purpose of this paper is two-fold. Firstly, we investigate regional-scale eruption records from the southern Chilean volcanic arc, supplemented by data from the Cascade and Kamchatka arcs, for evidence of post-glacial changes in volcanic activity. Secondly, we re-examine available global volcanic records in light of our arc results, and show that the sparseness of current records severely limits our ability to quantify global relationships between volcanic and climatic systems.

sections.heading: 1.1. Relationships between deglaciation and volcanism
sections.text:
Regional-scale studies in the non-arc settings of Iceland, continental Europe and eastern California all show clear evidence for increased volcanism following the end of glacial cycles (Glazner et al., 1999; Maclennan et al., 2002; Nowell et al., 2006). Iceland lies on a divergent plate boundary coincident with a mantle plume, and volcanism results from decompression melting of the upwelling mantle (Jull and McKenzie, 1996). Intraplate volcanism in continental Europe is also associatedwith decompressionmelting, potentially linked to amantle plume (Ritter et al., 2001), while that in eastern California results from mantle decompression in response to lithospheric extension (Hildreth, 2004).
In Iceland, geophysical modelling and geochemical evidence suggest that decompression following ice removal resulted in increased mantle melt production (Jull and McKenzie, 1996; Sinton et al., 2005; Pagli and Sigmundsson, 2008) and an increase in eruptive flux by up to two orders of magnitude (Hardarson and Fitton, 1991;
Sigvaldason et al., 1992; Slater et al., 1998; Maclennan et al., 2002). As well as enhanced melt production, the release of pooled magma (Sigvaldason et al., 1992; Sigvaldason, 2002) or shortened crustal residence times (Gee et al., 1998; Jellinek et al., 2004) may explain increased eruption rates.
It has also been argued that both rapid sea-level rise (Nakada and Yokose, 1992) and fall (Rampino et al., 1979; Wallman et al., 1988), associated with changes in global ice mass, have led to enhanced volcanic eruption rates in a range of settings (cf. McGuire et al., 1997). Additionally, climatic changes associated with glacial cycles may not only affect magmatic processes, but also control the timing of volcanic edifice collapse (Capra, 2006; Quidelleur et al., 2008) and the dynamics of associated landslides (Capra et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 1.2. Evidence of increased arc-volcanic eruptions following deglaciation
sections.text:
Current evidence for post-glacial increases in arc volcanism is ambiguous, and generally based only on individual study sites. Temporal variations in effusive eruptive flux at Mt. Mazama, in the Cascade arc (Bacon and Lanphere, 2006) and Tatara–San Pedro and Puyehue– Cordón Caulle, in Chile (Singer et al., 1997, 2008) have been attributed to glacial cycles. However, due to large dating errors and volumetric uncertainties associated with edifice erosion and growth, patterns in effusive flux can only be resolved at ~10 kyr timescales. Additionally, detailed data of this type are available from very few locations (cf. White et al., 2006; Singer et al., 2008; Völker et al., 2011).
Tephrochronological sequences, which record only explosive eruptions, can provide a much higher resolution record, or alternatively be used to assess volcanic activity on regional scales (e.g., Bigg et al., 2008). Kutterolf et al. (2013) used 408 tephras from Pacific sea-floor cores, deposited over the past 1.15 Ma, to demonstrate a 41 kyr periodicity in volcanic activity, and thereby attribute increased volcanism to periods of rapid sea level rise. However, this analysis was based on a relatively small number of eruptions for any one glacial cycle. Tephra deposits in recent soil or sediment sequences potentially provide a much more comprehensive eruption record, which may allow better quantification of the changes that occurred after the last glaciation. For example, the two lake-core examples in Fig. 1 (de Fontaine et al., 2007; Bertrand et al., 2008a) show clustering onmillennial timescales, suggestive of underlying controls on eruption timing (cf. Gusev et al., 2003). However, the patterns in each core differ, and the data from Lake Puyehue counter the conclusion of an increased post-glacial volcanic flux derived from mapped lava flows at the nearby Puyehue– Cordón Caulle volcano (Singer et al., 2008). Many volcanoes display episodic eruption patterns (e.g., Hildreth, 2007), and examining individual locations may provide coincidental or contradictory correlations between periods of ice retreat and elevated volcanism. A rigorous assessment of such relationships therefore requires examination of eruption data on a regional scale. If a glacial control on volcanism exists at individual volcanoes, then by combining data from several volcanoes this pattern should be amplified. Alternatively, if temporal variation in volcanism is random, variability across an entire region will be attenuated through averaging.

sections.heading: 2. Investigating the impact of deglaciation on arc volcanism
2.1. Glaciated volcanic arcs and site selection
sections.text:
Ice was present across several volcanic arcs at the LGM (Siegert, 2001; Clark et al., 2009). The extent of ice cover ranged from small mountain glaciers, housed on individual edifices, through to broad ice sheets with thicknesses in excess of 1000 m. We assume that the greater the change in ice volume between the LGM and the Holocene, the more likely that a volcanic response will be observable. For this investigation, we therefore focus on arcs that were extensively glaciated.
Extensive ice cover, which we define as the presence of continuous LGM ice cover between adjacent Pleistocene–Holocene stratovolcanoes over distances of >100 km, affected four arcs. In southern Chile, the Patagonian ice sheet extended for several hundred kilometres along the Andes (McCulloch et al., 2000). The northernmost part of the Cascade arc and the eastern part of the Alaska– Aleutian arc were similarly affected by a thick ice-sheet (Siegert, 2001). LGM ice cover in Kamchatka was less extensive and is less well constrained, but continuous ice fields certainly covered much of the arc (Zamoruyev, 2004; Bigg et al., 2008). Less extensive ice, forming substantial ice caps but with discontinuous cover between volcanoes, affected the equatorial and tropical Andes (Clapperton, 1993; Smith et al., 2005), the southern part of the Cascade arc, the Aleutian Islands (Siegert, 2001), and Japan (Sawagaki et al., 2004; Ono et al., 2005). For these locations, the precise ice extent at the LGM is relatively poorly constrained.
To investigate the impact of deglaciation on arc volcanism three other criteria, in addition to extensive LGM ice cover, would ideally be met: (1) The extent of ice cover and the timing of ice retreat would be well constrained; (2) The majority of volcanoes across a long segment of the arc would have been subjected to ice cover; and (3) The timing and magnitude of volcanic activity from the LGM to the present day would be well constrained. In reality, the third criterion is the least likely to be met, since available data are generally limited to large eruptions and to the period following ice retreat (see Section 2.3).
The above criteria led us to select the Andean southern volcanic zone (SVZ; 33°–46° S), in southern Chile, as the best test site for constraining the arc-scale volcanic response to deglaciation. Here, more stratovolcanoes were affected by an ice sheet of >1000-m thickness than in any other arc. The Patagonian ice sheet, where it extended
over the southern SVZ, was broader (up to 300 km) than in any arc except for the northernmost Cascade and Alaskan arcs, where the Cordilleran ice sheet was of a similar scale (Broecker and Denton, 1989; Andersen et al., 1999; McCulloch et al., 2000; Clark et al., 2009). Moreover, in southern Chile the prevailing winds disperse tephra across the continent, meaning that widely-preserved tephra deposits provide a good post-glacial eruption record (e.g., Naranjo and Stern, 2004; Watt et al., 2011b). In Kamchatka, ice cover was less extensive (Bigg et al., 2008), while only the northern part of the Cascade arc was affected by a thick ice sheet. Eruption data coverage in the Cascades and Kamchatka is comparable to that from Chile. We therefore structure this paper as follows: Section 3 examines the Chilean data in detail, and these are then compared to the Cascade and Kamchatka arcs in Section 4. Although good eruption records exist from individual volcanoes in Alaska (e.g., Miller and Smith, 1987; Payne et al., 2008), the total number of records is relatively small, and records from the Alaska–Aleutian arc are not considered further. A summary of the datasets used in this study is given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Arc-scale records: sampling rate (ER) and eruption magnitude
sections.text:
For past eruptions, we refer to the ratio of known events versus the number of actual events as the eruption sampling rate, ER. ER is widely variable in space and time, and can only be estimated, since the actual number of eruptions is unknown. However, it is evident that ER approaches unity in the recent past (i.e. nearly all eruptions are recorded; Siebert and Simkin, 2002-), but decreases rapidly for prehistoric times (Deligne et al., 2010). Correcting for temporal sampling variation can be problematic, since remaining variability in the corrected record may either be due to uncertainties in the applied correction (since the temporal variation in ER can never be known precisely), or may reflect real variations in activity.
ER also varies with eruption magnitude. In our arc datasets, we compile all events with an estimated volume ≥0.01 km3. However, eruptions below 0.1 km3 are strongly under-sampled in comparison to larger events. This is indicated by the event size distribution in Fig. 2, where we expect a consistently sampled dataset to be described by a power law (i.e. plot as a straight line), except for the very largest eruptions (Simkin and Siebert, 2000; Gusev et al., 2003). The Chilean data fall slightly below a linear log–log relationship for volumes below 0.3 km3, and flatten more sharply below 0.1 km3, while those from Kamchatka fall sharply at b0.3 km3. The
record of large events is both more complete and relatively constant, and we therefore limit our analyses of arc-scale datasets to eruptions with a volume ≥0.1 km3 (Table 1) (≥0.3 km3 for Kamchatka).
Records of prehistoric effusive eruptions with good age and volumetric constraints are limited, and none are included in our Chilean dataset (Table 1). Thus, our volume limit of 0.1 km3 generally refers to explosive eruption products, and is equivalent to the boundary between Volcanic Explosivity Index (VEI; Newhall and Self, 1982) 3 and 4. For Kamchatka, our data are again dominated by explosive eruptions, but include a small percentage of effusive products (Table 1). In contrast, most of our Cascades dataset comprises mapped effusive or mixed volcanic deposits, but this comes at the expense of well defined eruption ages, with many “eruptions” representing episodes thatmay contain several discrete effusive or explosive eruptions (Hildreth, 2007).
Large explosive eruptions disperse their products over a wide area, and the good spatial coverage of detailed field studies in our studied arcs explains why ER for these events is consistent (and, we would suggest, relatively high) (De la Cruz-Reyna, 1991; Simkin and Siebert, 2000). Prior to the most recent 1–2 kyr, where we expect historical records and good exposure, preservation or sampling of the shallowest soil and sediment sequences to increase ER, there is no reason to suggest that ER for large explosive eruptions should vary significantly during the post-glacial period (cf. Deligne et al., 2010). This is confirmed by Fig. 2B, which shows that the consistently-sampled larger eruptions are spread relatively evenly across post-glacial time, before 2 ka. We do not, therefore, apply a temporal sampling correction. For smaller events, not only is their sampling rate far lower, but this sampling is very strongly skewed towards the past 1 kyr.
The Cascades data have a less clear linear section in Fig. 2A than the other arc datasets. This suggests that the rate of recording decreases continuously with decreasing eruption size, and may reflect the fact that this dataset encompasses all eruptive products (but predominantly lavas, as for the Icelandic data in Fig. 2A), in contrast to the other arc records. The compilation of the Cascades dataset (Hildreth, 2007) aimed to be comprehensive in terms of volume, and it provides a better reflection of total eruptive flux than our other arc datasets (although there is a higher proportion of unrepresented volcanoes than in our Chilean dataset; Table 1). However, many of the recorded events potentially package several eruptions into single eruptive episodes. The likelihood of amalgamating eruptions in this way will increase as eruption size decreases, particularly for lavas, which may be buried or hard to map or date separately, thus explaining the curved form of the magnitude–frequency plot.

sections.heading: 2.3. Assumptions and limitations
sections.text:
Tephrochronological records have the potential to reveal eruptionrate variability on centennial to millennial timescales (Fig. 1). In regional-scale datasets, such records are dominated by larger eruptions, commonly preserved as macroscopic layers in soil sequences (e.g., Naranjo and Stern, 2004). Smaller events, which produce thinner andmore locally dispersed deposits, are poorly represented. Although lake sediment cores may preserve more comprehensive deposit sequences (e.g., Bertrand et al., 2008a; Juvigné et al., 2008) and lead to higher-resolution regional-scale datasets in the future, it can be challenging to correlate smaller events both between sampling sites and to a source volcano, particularly given the currently sporadic coverage of such cores.
Tephras erupted during the last glaciation are unlikely to be preserved, at least proximally, due to a lack of suitable depositional environments (e.g., open lake water, actively accumulating peat mires or soil sequences). In many cases, the potential for preserving thin tephra deposits may only increase significantly following the re-establishment of a vegetation cover in formerly glaciated areas (cf. Pennington, 1986; Frenot et al., 1998; Levesque and Svoboda, 1999; Kilian et al., 2007).
As a consequence, our datasets from glaciated arcs are limited to postglacial time.
Given the nature of our datasets from Chile and Kamchatka, we must assume that large explosive eruptions provide a proxy for total volcanic activity. Eruption style may well be modulated by ice cover during glaciations (Smellie and Skilling, 1994; Carrivick et al., 2009). However, given that there is no significant change in ice cover during the post-glacial period, we would expect any increase in early postglacial volcanism, relative to the present day, to be manifested (approximately) proportionately through explosive activity. Furthermore, although the predominant style of activity at individual volcanoes may vary on millennial timescales, the largest explosive eruptions (up to VEI 7) dominate the long-term erupted mass flux across wider spatial scales (Pyle, 1995; Simkin and Siebert, 2000), and should therefore provide a good indication of arc-wide patterns in volcanic activity.
Previous regional-scale studies of the relationship between volcanism and glaciation have used data of variable quality. In Iceland, dating of both tephra deposits and lava flows (e.g., Maclennan et al., 2002; Sinton et al., 2005) provides a relatively comprehensive volcanic record, although effusive eruption rates in the earliest part of therecord are subject to some uncertainty. Records from eastern California (Glazner et al., 1999) and continental Europe (Nowell et al., 2006) are subject to much larger dating errors and lack volumetric information, but they have the advantage of spanning several glaciations. In all cases, datasets are biased towards larger-volume eruptions, a problem inherent to reconstructions of past volcanic activity. This is particularly the case in settings where activity is focussed at stratovolcanoes (i.e. arcs such as southern Chile), rather than in dispersed volcanic fields, since edifice erosion and subsequent activity render reconstruction of small-volume or non-explosive activity difficult. In addition, glacial-age eruption records are sparse for all datasets. A glacially-driven change in volcanism is thus generally deduced by comparing activity in the immediate post-glacial period with later post-glacial time, the assumption being that deglaciation only temporarily perturbs the magmatic system (whether via increased melting or by melt release). There is no assumption that later post-glacial rates of volcanism return to a level characteristic of glacial periods, but since the latter is so poorly known, this is not easily testable. However, as discussed in Section 3.4, the two are likely to differ.
In summary, two caveats to our approach should be considered: first, records based only on explosive volcanism cannot be used to investigate changes in eruptive style; second, because our arc-scale datasets are restricted to the post-glacial period, we cannot directly compare post-glacial eruption rates with those during the last glaciation. However, long-term changes in volcanism may be deduced if activity in the early post-glacial period is elevated, over a period of finite duration, relative to the later Holocene. For example, the postglacial pulse in Icelandic volcanism lasted for ~2 kyr (Maclennan et al., 2002), and postulated increases in activity from individual arc volcanoes, although less well constrained, have a duration of a few thousand years (e.g., Bacon and Lanphere, 2006; Singer et al., 2008). It is therefore reasonable to expect that a volcanic response to deglaciation would be observable within the 10–15 kyr period of our arc datasets.

sections.heading: 3. Post-glacial volcanism and deglaciation in southern Chile
3.1. Eruption records
sections.text:
We have compiled tephrochronological data, recording event age and magnitude, for an 800-km segment of the Andean SVZ, between Llaima (38.7° S) and Hudson (45.9° S) volcanoes in southern Chile (Table 2 and references therein). Table 2 lists 121 eruptions with volumes ≥0.01 km3, from 26 volcanoes. Records of smaller events are almost entirely limited to historical time. Of the 121 eruptions
in Table 2, 87 (from 24 volcanoes) have a volume ≥0.1 km3. The 34 smaller events account for just 0.7% of the total erupted volume (Table 1), and their strong relative under-representation is confirmed by Fig. 2 (see Section 2.2.). Thirty-three regional volcanoes are likely to have been active in post-glacial time, and the centres unrepresented in Table 2 are either little-studied or have only experienced effusive or small-magnitude eruptions. If deglaciation did influence arc volcanism across regional scales, a lack of data from these littlestudied volcanoes would not affect this pattern.
Records from individual volcanoes highlight the strong control of magnitude on prehistoric eruption identification. For example, at Calbuco the tephrochronological record (Table 2; Watt et al., 2011b) includes thirteen events, suggesting a mean eruption interval approaching 1000 years. In contrast, historical eruptions from Calbuco have occurred with an average repeat time of a few decades (Siebert and Simkin, 2002-) but only one of these, in 1893, approached the magnitude of the smallest eruptions in the tephrochronological record. It is notable that eleven of the thirteen Calbuco tephras were deposited within b4 kyr in the early Holocene. However, the timing of this elevated activity, shortly after regional deglaciation, may be coincidental, and we must test whether such patterns persist across the arc as a whole. In fact, because most of the studied volcanoes have experienced very few large post-glacial explosive eruptions, only an approach that combines these data can be used to elucidate any meaningful patterns.
Evidence of glacial-age volcanism in Chile is often limited to subglacial lavas, which have been studied at very few volcanoes (e.g., Nevados de Chillán (Dixon et al., 1999; Mee et al., 2009), Puyehue–Cordón Caulle (Singer et al., 2008)). Even in these cases the uncertainties in eruption volume and age are generally far larger than for tephra deposits, and we have therefore not integrated these records with our dataset.
We selected Llaima as the northern terminus of the studied arc segment for two reasons. Firstly, Llaima lies at the end of a continuous narrow arc extending northwards from Hudson (Fig. 3), for which the tephra-stratigraphy has been well studied. Further north, the arc broadens (Stern, 2004) and eruption records are more sparse. Secondly, south of Llaima the Patagonian ice-sheet was sufficiently thick to feed piedmont ice lobes, which extended beyond the main mountain chain (McCulloch et al., 2000), while to the north the presence of ice was restricted to volumetrically much smaller bodies along the Andean mountain belt.
Tephra deposit ages (Table 2) are all based on calibrated radiocarbon dates, using OxCal4.0 (Bronk Ramsey, 2009) and a Bayesian method for any sequences constrained by multiple dates (cf. Watt et al., 2011b). Our eruption ages are the mid-value of the calibrated age range at the 95.4% highest probability density. Events with an age uncertainty of greater than ±400 years are indicated in Table 2, and account for 23% of the dataset.
Explosive eruption volumes (Table 2) were constrained from mapped tephra deposit isopachs (Pyle, 1989, 1999) when such data were available (31% of the dataset; cf. Watt et al., 2011b). In other cases, volumes were estimated either directly from the quoted VEI or from field descriptions of eruptions and tephra deposits. Constraints tend to be poorer for smaller eruptions. Although some uncertainty is inevitable, it is not clear that this varies with age in our dataset, and it should not introduce systematic errors.We do not attempt to convert eruption volumes to mass, since deposit density information is rarely available. All our volumes are for explosive eruption deposits, which are likely to have broadly similar densities; this minimises the error associated with using volumes to represent explosive eruption flux.

sections.heading: 3.2. Deglaciation in southern Chile
sections.text:
The most recent glacial period, from ~90–12 ka, is known in Chile as the Llanquihue glaciation (Heusser, 1974), and is well recorded by
extensive glaciogenic deposits (Mercer, 1976; Porter, 1981; Rabassa and Clapperton, 1990). At the LGM, the Patagonian ice sheet extended for 2000 km along the Andes, between 56° S and 37° S (Fig. 3). Ice-sheet thickness and width increased southwards, with marine glacial termini south of 43° S (Andersen et al., 1999; McCulloch et al., 2000; Glasser et al., 2008). Deglaciation of the southern Chilean volcanoes occurred from 18 to 11 ka, with ice persisting for longer in the south (Denton et al., 2010). Hudson (45.9° S) is still extensively glaciated at the present day, and lies a little north of the North Patagonian ice-field, a remnant of Llanquihue ice cover (Glasser et al., 2004).
Temperatures at the LGM were up to 6–7 °C lower than present, and precipitation was significantly higher (Heusser et al., 2000; Moreno et al., 2001; Denton et al., 2010). The glacier equilibrium line was ~1000 m below present levels (Porter, 1981; Denton et al., 1999b). Ice-sheet modelling (Hulton et al., 2002) suggests that north
of 43° S, ice thickness exceeded 1000 m only in the high Andes, but that south of 43° S (Minchinmávida–Hudson; Fig. 3), with a width broadening to 300 km, the average ice thickness was >1000 m, giving a total ice volume of >5 × 105 km3 at the LGM.
The progression of ice retreat is summarised in Fig. 3 and Table 3 (Ariztegui et al., 1997; Andersen et al., 1999; McCulloch et al., 2000; Hajdas et al., 2003; Rabassa et al., 2005; Glasser et al., 2008). To allow consistent comparison with our eruption records, ages of climatic events are based on calibrated radiocarbon dates. Regional deglaciation occurred rapidly after the LGM (Rabassa and Clapperton, 1990; Denton et al., 1999a), with an initial warming (~17.5 ka) leaving a much reduced ice sheet. North of 45° S, continuous ice cover was restricted to high ground. Subsequent climatic changes produced a complex pattern of glacial advance and retreat that was not necessarily regionally coherent (McCulloch et al., 2000; Lamy et al., 2004; Heusser and Heusser, 2006; Kaplan et al., 2008; Zech et al., 2008), but does show at least broad correlation with late-glacial fluctuations recorded in the Northern Hemisphere (Lowell et al., 1995; Ariztegui et al., 1997; Denton et al., 1999a; Moreno et al., 2001). Data from the Tronador ice-cap (41° S) indicate extensive advances as late as 12.5 ka (Ariztegui et al., 1997), as part of a regional cold reversal from 13.3 to 11.8 ka (Hajdas et al., 2003). At 40° S, evidence for low-altitude ice advances during this same period is absent (Bertrand et al., 2008b; Sterken et al., 2008; cf. Zech et al., 2008). A final warming stage at 11.4 ka left temperature conditions and ice extent similar to that of today (Denton et al., 1999a; McCulloch et al., 2000; Glasser et al., 2004; Kilian et al., 2007).
We use the term post-glacial to refer to ages younger than the final retreat of low-altitude ice. In the south of the study region, 11.4 ka may be taken as the onset of the post-glacial period. Further north, the initial warming step left only mountain ice cover after ~17 ka. Thus, the onset of post-glacial time in southern Chile, which marks the base of present-day soil sequences and the establishment of environments suitable for tephra deposit preservation, varied with latitude and is bracketed between 17 ka and 11.4 ka.

sections.heading: 3.3. Eruption data interpretation
sections.text: A plot of eruption volume against time (Fig. 4) shows that the early post-glacial period included some of the largest known eruptions in the SVZ, including those at Llaima (Curacautín ignimbrite), Villarrica (Licán ignimbrite) and Hudson (H1 tephra). Relatively small eruptions cluster towards the past two millennia, particularly in the north of the arc segment. Fig. 4 indicates that tephra flux varies widely in space and time, as has been found for total magmatic flux in Chile and elsewhere (Singer et al., 2008; Völker et al., 2011). We suggest that this dominance of the record by a few volcanic centres is real: Hudson has previously been suggested to be far more active than volcanoes immediately to the north (Naranjo and Stern, 2004), and the prominence of Llaima and Villarrica in Fig. 4 corresponds with their high historical levels of activity.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Record length and ice retreat
sections.text:
South of 41° S, the absence of data before 11.4 ka most likely reflects a lack of tephra preservation, rather than a lack of activity. The outliers to this pattern (i.e. the older deposits from Hudson in Fig. 4; Haberle and Lumley, 1998; Carel et al., 2011) are tephra deposits sampled in lake sediments from islands west of the volcano. This environment may have been protected from late-glacial ice advances, since no tephra deposits of comparable age have been found in extensive studies on the Andean side of Hudson (Naranjo and Stern, 1998). Further sampling in distal environments, beyond the ice-sheet limits, would help extend the volcanic record at these latitudes into the late-glacial period (e.g., Stern, 2008; Carel et al., 2011; Stern et al., 2011); the paucity of such studies is a shortcoming of the tephrochronological record in this region. We assume that all eruptions in Fig. 4 (except the noted outliers) post-date the final ice retreat at their latitude of deposition, because proximal tephra deposits, which account for most of the records, would not otherwise be preserved.
Many of the oldest proximal tephra deposits in southern Chile are deposited on glacial till or glacially scoured bedrock (Watt et al., 2011b), and provide a rough proxy for the age of final ice retreat from the inland valleys where the deposits have generally been sampled. This tephra-based record contrasts with the terminal moraine samples generally used to reconstruct the progress of deglaciation (e.g., McCulloch et al., 2000; Rabassa et al., 2005; Glasser et al., 2008), which record the retreat of ice from its maximum extent. The latitudinal range of our dataset makes it worth examining from this perspective.
Our oldest recorded eruptions define preservation age limits (the “baselines” in Fig. 4), enclosing the records on the old side of the dataset. The simplest fit joins the Licán ignimbrite from Villarrica and the Palena eruptions. However, eruptions south of ~41° S are much more closely fitted by a line joining Yan1 and Ca1 (Table 2; Fig. 4). Palena (11.4 ka) falls outside this baseline. This eruption, associated with a set of monogenetic cones, is categorically different from most of the dataset, which records eruptions from arc-frontal stratovolcanoes. The timing of the Palena eruption is discussed further in Section 3.4.2.
The Ca1–Yan1 baseline can be used to approximate ice retreat south of ~41° S. A simplistic (in all likelihood, over-simplistic) interpretation of its slope suggests a southward retreat of the low-altitude ice-front of ~30 km per century. North of 41° S much older eruptions (up to 16.5 ka) are preserved, whereas to the south all eruptions (except Palena) are younger than 10.5 ka. These limits of tephra preservation are consistent with independent records of deglaciation (Fig. 3; Table 3), in terms of the initial warming at 17.5 ka (McCulloch et al., 2000), the northern limit of recorded late-glacial ice readvances (~41° S; Ariztegui et al., 1997; Hajdas et al., 2003), and the final stage of deglaciation in the far south at 11.4 ka. South of ~41° S, the lack of preserved tephras before 11.5 ka suggests that the northern edge of the ice sheet (Fig. 3), although likely to have been narrow and potentially discontinuous, extended 250 km further
north during the late-glacial than the mapped limit of McCulloch et al. (2000), at ~43° S.
Although there is a general correlation between our pattern of tephra preservation and the regional progression of ice retreat, there is a lag of 1–2 kyr between the main warming stages and the oldest identified eruptions from arc stratovolcanoes (Table 3). After this 1–2 kyr period, the volcanic record is marked by several notably large explosive eruptions. Possible reasons for the lag are discussed in Section 3.4.1.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Eruption rate analysis
sections.text:
For our Chilean data, a cumulative plot of erupted volume against age fits an approximately straight line (Fig. 5A), suggesting a roughly constant eruptive flux. The initial, steep part of the curve corresponds to three large eruptions from Villarrica and Llaima (Fig. 4), but beyond this there is no clear variability in the long-term eruption rate. Eruption frequency is in fact substantially lower in the first third of the record (2.4 per kyr), and inter-event intervals are non-stationary (the statistical parameters describing the data vary through time), showing a steady decrease towards the present, albeit with a deviation to lower eruption frequencies in the mid-Holocene (Fig. 5A). However, the non-stationary trend is attributable to an absence of data in the earliest post-glacial period for the southernmost part of the arc (Fig. 4), due to widespread ice cover. Hence, eruption rate variations may be obscured if calendar-age data alone are considered. We therefore reassess arc-scale volcanic flux by analysing a comparable time period across all latitudes. We define this period using the baselines discussed in Section 3.3.1, along with an equivalent parallel that intersects the southern end of the arc at the present day (Fig. 4). This allows a simple interpretation of volcanic records coupled to climatic changes.
The Licán–Palena baseline does not fit our eruption records particularly closely, but can be used to interpret the entire study region. The 8833-year record defined by this line suggests an elevated early post-glacial eruption rate (Fig. 5C; 54% of the total tephra volume erupted during the first 27% of the time period), but this is entirely accounted for by three large eruptions (Licán, Curacautín and H1) from Villarrica, Llaima and Hudson (Fig. 4). Although these very
large eruptions may represent some form of post-glacial response, there is no trend or episodicity in eruption frequency (Fig. 5B).
An alternative approach is to consider data south of 41° S, which is tightly enclosed by the Ca1–Yan1 baseline (Fig. 4). For this arc segment (Osorno–Hudson), interpretations are limited statistically by the small size of the sample, but records do show some evidence for temporal trends: the mid-Holocene eruption frequency is reduced relative to the early Holocene, with inter-event times exceeding the 95% confidence interval that is expected for a stationary eruption sequence (Fig. 5D). Eruption rates vary by a factor of two over this time (5.3 versus 2.7 eruptions-per-kyr between the early and middle part of the study period). Hudson dominates the volumetric flux (Fig. 5E), but for the remaining volcanoes (Osorno–Maca) nearly three times as many eruptions occur in the first third of the defined post-glacial period than in the second (Fig. 5F). Eruption magnitude over the same period shows no clear variation.
In our null hypothesis, of no dependence between ice retreat and eruption occurrence, eruptions should follow a stationary Poisson point-process (e.g., Cox and Isham, 1980), with inter-event times that are independent and identically distributed, described by an exponential distribution (cf. Bebbington and Lai, 1996; Gusev et al., 2003; Bebbington, 2010). If the data do not fit the exponential distribution, this would suggest a reason to reject the null hypothesis. In particular, we may expect eruption clustering (short inter-event intervals) in the early post-glacial period. Our Osorno–Hudson data hint at such a pattern, with a mid-Holocene eruption frequency that is lower than expected (Fig. 5F). However, a Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for the exponential (Lilliefors, 1969) does not reject the null hypothesis at the 90% significance level (the same result is obtained for the Licán–Palena baseline dataset). This is not surprising, given the small size of our dataset (N = 36). It is difficult to demonstrate non-stationarity in a point process unless the effects of the modulating mechanism cause a strong deviation from the steady-state event frequency, and a larger dataset would be required to demonstrate the statistical significance of our observed pattern.
Although the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test does not support rejection of the exponential distribution for our eruption data, a graphical assessment of inter-event intervals, t, may still be informative for
assessing evidence of clustering. Deviation from an exponential cumulative distribution function [F(t) = 1 − exp(−t / t0), where t0 is the scale parameter, estimated as the mean inter-event interval], towards a Weibull fit [F(t) = 1 − exp(−(t / t0)γ), where γ is the shape parameter, and t0 and γ are estimated here from probability plots (cf. Gusev et al., 2003; Watt et al., 2007)] would suggest either
clustering (for γ b 1) or periodicity (for γ > 1) (Gusev et al., 2003; Marzocchi and Zaccarelli, 2006; Bebbington, 2010). When γ = 1 the Weibull reduces to the exponential function. As expected from our earlier analysis, data from the Licán–Palena dataset (Fig. 5B) show a good fit to the exponential distribution (Fig. 6). Again, the small dataset size limits the strength of any conclusions that may be drawn from apparent patterns within the dataset. Additionally, the short temporal length of the dataset means that cyclic or periodic patterns may not be manifested at statistically significant levels (cf. Bebbington, 2010). In summary, eruption frequency in the Ca1–Yan1 dataset approximately halves from the early- to mid-Holocene (Fig. 5D), and this is potentially consistent with a quasi-cyclic variation in activity on a timescale related to deglaciation (5–10 kyr). However, such variation, overprinting background eruption behaviour, is not statistically significant at the available sample size.

sections.heading: 3.4. Chilean data: summary and discussion
sections.text:
Beneath the thickest and broadest part of the Patagonian ice sheet (south of 41° S), when the latitudinally-variable timing of deglaciation is taken into consideration, eruption frequency was up to a factor of two higher during the ~5 kyr period after deglaciation, than in the later Holocene (Fig. 5D). However, this observation is based on a small dataset, and is not statistically significant; nor is it apparent when a wider segment of the arc is analysed. The ~5 kyr period after regional deglaciation also coincides with notably large explosive eruptions from the region'smost active volcanoes: Llaima, Villarrica and Hudson. Large eruptions also occurred around this time at Mocho– Choshuenco, Calbuco, Chaitén and Yanteles (Fig. 4), but there is no clear increase in eruption magnitude as a whole during this period if events at Llaima, Villarrica and Hudson are discounted. In order to discuss the mechanisms that may explain the above patterns in volcanic activity, we provide a summary of the potential impacts of deglaciation on arc volcanism in Fig. 7.
In rift or intraplate settings such as Iceland and continental Europe, enhanced melt production, through decompression, is the most likely cause of a post-glacial pulse in volcanism. Given the more limited post-glacial changes in volcanism, increased melt production does not need to be invoked in southern Chile. Here, observed patterns may simply reflect the enhanced release of crustally-stored melt due to changes in the prevailing upper crustal stress state (e.g., Stewart et al., 2000; Jellinek et al., 2004). Although ice thickness in Chile (~1000 m) was comparable to that in Iceland, corresponding to an

effective lithostatic pressure release of a few hundred metres upon retreat, and although the lack of a clear residual post-glacial uplift signal suggests a rapid isostatic response to ice removal (cf. Lambeck et al., 1990; Ivins and James, 1999, 2004), it is not clear whether such processes may enhance the degree of partial melting within subduction zones (cf. Plank and Langmuir, 1988; Huybers and Langmuir, 2009). The thermal structure of subduction zones,which are dominated by volatile-drivenmelting in the hot core of themantlewedge (Schmidt and Poli, 1998; Grove et al., 2012), may reduce the impact of lithospheric unloading on overall rates of melting, and will also be sensitive to the lateral extent of the ice load that is removed.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Timing of the arc response to deglaciation
sections.text:
There is a lag of 1–2 kyr between final ice retreat and the earliest recorded post-glacial tephra deposits in southern Chile (Table 3 and Fig. 4). This lag is based on well-constrained ages for climatic and volcanic events, derived frommultiple radiocarbon dates. In apparent contrast to Chile, the period of increased volcanism in Iceland occurred almost immediately after deglaciation (Maclennan et al., 2002),finishing within 2 kyr.
The time lag in Chile may reflect a characteristic timescale of crustal magma ascent. In eastern California, a time of ~3 kyr has been estimated for the enhanced ascent of upper crustal magmas following the maximum rate of ice retreat (Jellinek et al., 2004). The lag may also reflect the timing of maximum upper crustal strain following ice retreat. An ice sheet overprints the prevailing tectonic stress state (Stewart et al., 2000), and in compressive or strike-slip regimes, such as southern Chile, the increase in vertical stress reduces the differential stress (Fig. 7; Johnston, 1989). Deglaciation abruptly removes the vertical load, with glacio-isostatic recovery comprising an elastic lithospheric flexure and a viscoelastic asthenospheric flow response. Flexural stresses may reach tens of MPa for an ice sheet of 1 km thickness, producing large horizontal strain rates (Stein et al., 1989; Stewart et al., 2000) and a period of intense upper crustal deformation (Hampel and Hetzel, 2006), but this may not reach its maximum for several thousand years within the bounds of the former ice-sheet (Beck et al., 1996; Stewart et al., 2000). In addition, some delay in the actual unloading of the crust may have resulted from the formation of pro-glacial lakes, which potentially stored meltwater for 1–2 kyr before draining (Stern et al., 2011).

Stresses affecting the immediate surroundings of crustally-stored magma are also likely to control eruption timing (e.g., Pagli and Sigmundsson, 2008; Albino et al., 2010). Ice loads smaller in diameter than the lithospheric elastic thickness (20–25 km in this region; Pérez-Gussinyé et al., 2008) are supported by the lithosphere's strength. Elastic recovery on their removal is accompanied by rapid local changes in strain rates (Cohen, 1993; Sauber et al., 2000) and edifice deformation (Pinel et al., 2007). If local (edifice-scale) ice bodies were present on high edifices relatively later during deglaciation, and exerted the main control on eruption timing, then this could also contribute to the apparent delay in eruption timing. However, there is no evidence to suggest that higher altitude ice retreat significantly lagged the regional scale retreat (McCulloch et al., 2000), and the limited size of our dataset does not permit meaningful comparison between edifice altitude and eruption timing.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Enhanced crustal storage of magma
sections.text:
The reduction in vertical stress following ice retreat increases magmatic overpressure and the probability of stored magma reaching a critical eruptive state. Conversely, during glaciation the probability of eruption is suppressed (Fig. 7). In a simple elastic model (uniaxial strain; cf. Glazner et al., 1999), 1000 m of ice increases the horizontal stress by ~3 MPa, comparable to the excess pressure involved in dyke formation (Rubin, 1995). This load is potentially sufficient to impede vertical magma movement. Thus, enhanced ponding of magma during glaciation, and its subsequent release, may account for the very large explosive eruptions in the early post-glacial period at Llaima, Hudson and Villarrica (Fig. 4; cf. Lohmar et al., 2012). Particularly at active systems such as these, a high magma flux would promote significant melt accumulation in the upper crust. Elsewhere, a lower magma flux may mean that a pattern of enhanced storage is harder to discern, given the uncertainties within our dataset.
If crustal magma storage was enhanced during glaciation, then the products of early post-glacial eruptions should be relatively more evolved. Available data suggest that this is at least plausible: at Villarrica, post-Licán rocks are less silicic than the Licán ignimbrite, and while this is less clear at Llaima, the mineralogy of the Curacautín ignimbrite suggests a highly homogeneous stock of magma, contrasting with later zoned and more widely variable compositions (Lohmar et al., 2005). No clear age-composition trend is seen at Hudson.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Deglaciation, fault activation and volcanism
sections.text:
Deglaciation may cause fault reactivation (Mörner, 1978; Stein et al., 1989; Beck et al., 1996; Turpeinen et al., 2008) both within and beyond ice-sheet boundaries (James and Bent, 1994). We speculate that such enhanced faulting may have promoted the ascent of primitive magmas at Palena (Fig. 3) and other monogenetic clusters of cones during the early post-glacial period.
The Palena scoria deposits (43.8° S) are dated at ~11.5 ka (Heusser et al., 1992; Watt, 2010), relatively earlier in the post-glacial period than more evolved tephra deposits from the arc front (Fig. 4). The Palena eruption formed a series of cinder cones along a 30 km lineament behind the arc front, associated with the regional-scale transpressional Liquiñe–Ofqui fault zone (LOFZ; Fig. 3). The scoria deposits lie on thin post-glacial soils, and appear to have erupted over a relatively short time period, without preceding or subsequent activity. Their primitive chemistry (Watt, 2010) implies rapid ascent from depth.
Enhanced deformation may have occurred along the LOFZ in the early post-glacial period, potentially allowing magma ponded at the base of the crust to rise rapidly (Fig. 7). The greatest strain rates would have occurred beneath the widest part of the former ice sheet (south of 43° S), where its width of 300 km far exceeded the lithospheric elastic thickness (Mörner, 1978; Johnston, 1989; Johnston et al., 1998). Rapid changes in strain rate may have temporarily provided conditions more conducive to dyke ascent, otherwise inhibited by the prevailing stress regime (cf. Ziv et al., 2000). It is
possible that a similar explanation applies to the Puyuhuapi eruptions further south (Fig. 3), although the eruption timing fits less clearly in this case (Table 2). Localised ascent of magmas along faults within transpressional systems is relatively widespread (e.g., De Saint Blanquat et al., 1998). Indeed, small volumes of decompression melting may facilitate fault movement (Gaffney et al., 2007) and promote magma ascent along the fracture plane.

sections.heading: 4. A comparison with eruption data from the Cascade and Kamchatka arcs
sections.text: As discussed in Section 2.1, the Cascade and Kamchatka arcs also provide suitable sites for investigating volcanic eruption rates following deglaciation. Extensive Holocene eruption data is available from both arcs (provided as Supplementary Data), and we analyse these datasets using the same approach as that for southern Chile. It should be noted that although the overall sizes of our three arc datasets are similar, in the Kamchatka and Cascades arcs there are higher proportions of unrepresented volcanoes (Table 1). Nevertheless, it is still likely that any glacially-driven variation in activity would be observable in the available data, and the purpose of these additional analyses is to assess whether our Chilean results, showing only limited evidence of a post-glacial enhancement of volcanism, are replicated elsewhere.

sections.heading: 4.1. Post-glacial volcanism in the Cascade arc
sections.text:
Hildreth (2007) provides a comprehensive summary of post-glacial eruptions in the Cascade arc, incorporating data from 18 volcanoes spanning a N–S distance of 1100 km (Fig. 8; Table 1). At the LGM, the Cordilleran ice sheet extended down the north-western edge of North America, covering the northernmost part of the Cascade arc (Fig. 8), and was contiguous with the larger Laurentide ice sheet to the east (Siegert, 2001; Clark et al., 2009). Ice thickness over the northern edge of the arc was ~1000 m (Marshall and Clarke, 1999), and therefore comparable to that in southern Chile. However, ice cover to the south was limited to mountain ice-caps, and we may therefore expect the magnitude of any arc-wide response to deglaciation to be smaller than that in southern Chile. Retreat of the Cordilleran ice sheet and of mountain glaciers further south is considered to have been synchronous (Clark et al., 2009), occurring gradually after 16–17 ka, and rapidly after 13 ka (Dyke and Prest, 1987; Siegert, 2001).
In contrast to the Chilean data, the Cascade dataset includes several effusive episodes, as well as explosive eruptions. Quoted eruption volumes (Hildreth, 2007) often combine lavas and tephra, but without density information these are not easily converted into a mass flux. Thus, we simply use the given volumes to interpret long-term rates of activity. Events that were not constrained to a particular age or age range have been excluded. Where an age range is given, we use the central value. This leaves a record comprising 83 eruptions (volume ≥0.1 km3) from 16.5 to 0 ka. Of these, 28% have ages constrained only within a >1 kyr range (Fig. 8A), and in some cases may represent eruptive episodes, potentially comprisingmultiple discrete eruptions during a period of elevated volcanism, rather than a single event. In common with the Chilean dataset, the Cascade data is dominated by large volume eruptions. As discussed in Section 2.2, the volume–frequency relationship in Fig. 2 is slightly curved, and although a broadly linear fit occurs at volumes ≥0.1 km3 (suggesting a consistent sampling rate), this is flatter than that for Chile and Kamchatka, and steepens for larger events. This shape may reflect the more complete nature of this dataset, comprising all eruption types, but may also be influenced by the amalgamation of multiple smaller eruptions into single volcanic units.
The post-glacial eruptive flux across the Cascade arc has been remarkably constant, (Fig. 8B and C), with the cumulative volume trend approximating a straight line. Similarly, inter-event intervals show no trend (Fig. 8D), except for a slight decrease towards the
past few kyr, which may be attributed to more precise dating and a slightly higher rate of eruption sampling. Inter-event intervals vary more widely than expected, suggesting event clustering, but without an obvious temporal pattern. Part of this may be an artefact of poor age constraints for many events in the early part of the record, where dates are only provided to the nearest thousand years and several eruptive episodes are assigned identical ages. Without accurate event times, evidence of clustering (as in Fig. 6) cannot be analysed further. Our interpretation is in agreement with Hildreth (2007), who asserted that eruption data from the arc show no evidence for coordinated episodicity.

sections.heading: 4.2. Post-glacial volcanism in Kamchatka
sections.text:
In Kamchatka, we base our records on a dataset of 43 regional tephra deposits (Braitseva et al., 1995, 1997; Ponomareva et al., 2007; Zaretskaya et al., 2007; Kyle et al., 2011), supplemented by data from Siebert and Simkin (2002-). The full dataset of 275 eruptions (volume ≥0.01 km3) is under-sampled below volumes of 0.3 km3 (Fig. 2). Rejecting these smaller events, we analyse a dataset of 105 eruptions since 10.4 ka, from 27 volcanoes spanning a N–S distance of nearly 700 km (Fig. 9). Of these eruptions, 13% include some effusive activity, but in all other respects the dataset is very similar to
that from Chile. Again, we base our analysis on quoted eruption volumes, because no density information is available. Uncalibrated eruption ages have been calibrated using OxCal4.0 (Bronk Ramsey, 2009).
Ice cover at the LGM in Kamchatka is generally considered to have been restricted to discontinuous mountain ice fields (Zamoruyev, 2004; Bigg et al., 2008). Ice thickness is poorly constrained, but these ice bodies had widths of 100 km in their widest parts (Fig. 9). There is evidence that ice was substantially more extensive at an earlier stage in the last glaciation, with a significant retreat at ~40 ka (Bigg et al., 2008). A similar pattern occurred in Japan, with the global LGM marking a much smaller ice extent (Ono et al., 2005). Bigg et al.
(2008) use the proportion of ash in Pacific Ocean sediment cores to suggest a period of enhanced explosive volcanism in southern Kamchatka and the Kurile Islands following the ~40 ka ice retreat.
Our data show broadly consistent levels of volcanism through the Holocene (Fig. 9), although there is evidence for clustering, with relatively reduced eruption frequencies in the mid-Holocene (Fig. 9D). This mid-Holocene gap is matched in the pattern from southern Chile (Fig. 5). The early Holocene also coincides with the Kurile Lake eruption, which dominates the overall eruptive flux for this period (Fig. 9C). The increased eruption frequency in the late Holocene may reflect the improved recognition (and perhaps preservation)
of younger eruptions, and is a pattern apparent across all of our arc records.
A Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for the exponential distribution (Lilliefors, 1969) rejects the null hypothesis (i.e. a stationary Poisson point-process, implying no dependence between ice retreat and eruption occurrence) at the 90% significance level, but not at the 95% level, therefore weakly supporting departure from a Poisson process for the Kamchatka inter-event times. Similarly, this is suggested by the slightly better visual fit to a Weibull cumulative distribution function, rather than an exponential distribution (Fig. 6), indicative of weak clustering (γ = 0.88). However, this deviation from the exponential, based on 1000 simulations of random data, is not statistically significant at the 90% level. Earlier work has concluded that large explosive eruptions in Kamchatka are clustered (Gusev et al., 2003; Ponomareva et al., 2007), with a greater tendency to clustering for the largest events. However, our larger dataset, which includes smaller eruptions, shows weaker evidence for clustering. It is possible that the clustering pattern therefore only holds for the very largest explosive eruptions.
Even if clustering is present within the Kamchatka dataset, this in itself does not indicate a response to deglaciation. To confidently assert a post-glacial response, we would require a relatively more pronounced cluster of eruptions in the early Holocene than at any other time in the record. Although there is an episode of relatively increased volcanic output from 9 to 7 ka (Fig. 9), this is no more prominent than later variations in eruption frequency.

sections.heading: 4.3. Summary of the arc volcanic response to deglaciation
sections.text:
The three arcs studied here are the best candidates worldwide for assessing the arc-volcanic response to deglaciation. No arc shows unequivocal evidence of a post-glacial enhancement in volcanism. The clearest suggestion of a volcanic response is in southern Chile (Andean SVZ), which, in the southern SVZ, was subjected to the greatest change in ice loading after the LGM. Here, several large eruptions occur in the first few thousand years after deglaciation, and eruption frequency for an ~3 kyr period, beginning ~2 kyr after the final retreat of low altitude ice, was up to twice that in the mid-Holocene, although only slightly higher than that in the late-Holocene (Fig. 5A and D). These observations could be explained by the enhanced release of pooled magma, and there is no need to invoke increased melt production. Data from Kamchatka provide some evidence for episodicity, again with a relatively low eruption frequency in the mid-Holocene. The Cascade arc shows a remarkably constant rate of activity since the LGM. Here, LGM ice cover over most of the arc was less than that in Chile and Kamchatka, and many volcanoes were affected only by mountain glaciation. We postulate that arcs glaciated to a similar extent, such as those of the central and northern Andes, and parts of Mexico and Japan, would have been affected to a similarly small, or even negligible, degree by ice retreat.
Our arc data do not support an increase in volcanic eruption rate of the order seen in non-arc volcano-tectonic settings (Maclennan et al., 2002; Nowell et al., 2006). For example, Sinton et al. (2005) showed from a dataset of 44 eruptions that there was a 7.5-fold increase in eruption frequency in Iceland's Western Volcanic Zone (WVZ) from 12 to 9 ka when compared to 4.5–0 ka, with no change in mean eruption volume. Parts of Iceland may have experienced a substantially larger pulse in volcanism. Maclennan et al. (2002) calculated increases in volcanic output (km3 per kyr) by factors of 25–47 for the period 12.5–10 ka relative to 10–0 ka, for four separate Icelandic sites. Much of this increase is due to several large-volume lava shields dated from 12.5 to 10 ka. However, the time period over which these effusive structures formed is not necessarily well constrained. It is also worth noting that the regional tephra record does not show a corresponding peak in activity (Gudmundsdóttir et al., 2012), although this could potentially reflect changes affecting tephra preservation
or the dominant style of eruptions. We plot the WVZ dataset (Sinton et al., 2005; D. Eason and J. Sinton, pers. comm.) in Fig. 2, and note that the linear slope (except for the expected deviation at the largest volumes) suggests consistent sampling rates, but is much flatter than the arc datasets, indicating a different volume– frequency relationship in this setting. Inter-eruption intervals for the WVZ (Fig. 10A) are strongly non-stationary, with the ten-point average interval lying below the 5th percentile for the oldest half of the dataset, before increasing to values above the 95th percentile for the most recent eruptions. Fig. 10B shows the per-kyr eruption rate normalised against the mean per-kyr rate for 10–0 ka, indicating an approximately 5-fold increase in volcanism during the early Holocene. No such striking changes in eruption frequency are observed in our arc data. All three arcs show a tendency towards increased eruption rates in the late Holocene, which may be attributed to relative over-sampling for this period.
Because there is some variability in eruption rates in individual arcs, it is possible that any patterns may be strengthened if all three arcs are analysed collectively. For this combination, we simply use calendar ages of eruptions. This is somewhat problematic, as it fails to account for differences in the timing of final ice retreat within the Chilean dataset, and also restricts our interpretation to ages younger than 10.4 ka, since not all datasets are fully represented before this time. We note, however, that the onset of post-glacial ice retreat was approximately coeval in each arc. Thus, assuming comparable timescales of any arc-magmatic response to deglaciation, any patterns in the data should combine additively. Furthermore, the timing of the maximum global increase in volcanism postulated by Huybers and Langmuir (2009) was from 12 to 7 ka; if this pattern is manifested in arcs, our records should be sufficiently long to observe this.
We collate all our records, and calculate a relative eruption frequency f across 1000-year time bins (Fig. 11). For each time bin, the eruption frequency n is normalised against the mean per-kiloyear eruption rate for the entire dataset from 3 to 10.4 ka, n′, and then set to vary around zero, such that f = (n / n′) − 1. This value is calculated at 100 year intervals. We select the period 3–10.4 ka for this calculation, because for ages younger than 3 ka data from each arc suggest a slightly higher eruption frequency (Fig. 10B), which may result from slightly higher levels of preservation and recording (i.e. relative over-sampling) over this time period. For ages older than 10.4 ka, our records are less comprehensive and have larger uncertainties, being limited to the Cascades and the northern part of our Chilean dataset. The eruption rate does decrease from 10.4 ka to 3 ka, but this pattern does not represent a statistically significant departure from stationarity, falling within the 2σ bounds derived from simulated randomly-sampled data. Similarly, the time-binned volume data for the three arcs show no evidence for temporal variation consistent with a post-glacial enhancement of eruption magnitude (Fig. 11). In summary, the results from three combined arcs remain equivocal, and do not statistically support a pattern of elevated volcanism in the early post-glacial period.
Although our datasets are generally limited to larger explosive eruptions (except for the Cascades), the compiled records are still likely to account for a substantial proportion of the entire post-glacial volcanic flux in these arcs. It therefore seems unlikely that the lack of a clear increase in volcanism following deglaciation can be attributed to biased records or sparse sampling. Rather, we suggest that the magnitude of the volcanic response to deglaciation was insufficiently large to be clearly observable at the resolution of our records (given uncertainties in age and magnitude estimates and a lack of data for small eruptions).
