Huybers and Langmuir (2009) postulated that global eruption rates increased by a factor of 2–6 from 12 to 7 ka. Our analyses of glaciated volcanic arcs suggest that an increase at the top end of this range is very unlikely. By critically reassessing the Huybers and Langmuir (2009) analysis of global eruption records, we attempt to marry our results from Chile, the Cascades and Kamchatka with their interpretations. We principally consider uncertainties inherent to global eruption records, in an effort to understand how well global variability in volcanism can be constrained, and the strength of conclusions that can be drawn from such data.

sections.heading: 5.1. The compilation of global eruption records
sections.text:
Huybers and Langmuir (2009) combined two existing global eruption datasets for their analysis. We use exactly the same data here, compiled from Bryson et al. (2006; 442 eruption ages, without magnitude information; 0–25 ka) and Siebert and Simkin (2002-; 4709 eruption ages, with estimated magnitudes as VEI; 0–11.8 ka) (Table 1). These datasets combine results from many disparate sources, and analytical difficulties relating to variable eruption sampling rates (see Section 2.2) are compounded. In an effort to reduce temporal sampling bias, eruptions of VEI b 2 (not ≤2, as was incorrectly written in Huybers and Langmuir, 2009) were removed from the Siebert and Simkin (2002-) data. The final dataset contains 5151 eruption ages (91.4% from Siebert and Simkin, 2002-), between A.D. 2004 and 25 ka, from ~530 volcanoes out of ~1500 that were potentially active in the Holocene (Siebert and Simkin, 2002-).
Following the method of Huybers and Langmuir (2009), we divide the global dataset into two subsets, separating areas glaciated at the LGM from non-glaciated areas. For simplicity, we refer to each subset as (formerly) ice-covered and ice-free regions, respectively. The boundary between ice-covered and ice-free regions is defined in the same way as Huybers and Langmuir (2009), using their −9 m/yr ice volume balance proxy (based on the ratio of modern accumulation and ablation rates) (Fig. 12A). This allows direct comparison with their results. Although this ice-limit proxy does not account for local mass-balance variations and includes some discrepancies, it provides a good general approximation of ice limits. For example, the ice-covered region includes low-latitude areas that are known to have been glaciated, such as the tropical Andes. Clearly, it also spans areas covered with thick ice sheets and those where ice was only present at high altitudes. The possible implications of such differences
(e.g., Tuffen, 2010) have already beenmentioned in relation to our arc data. However, for the purposes of a global analysis, a division into two categories based on the presence or absence of ice, is a reasonable first order approach to assess evidence of globally significant variations in volcanism.

sections.heading: 5.2. Effects of sampling rate variations on data interpretation
sections.text:
In Section 2.2 we discussed how corrections for a variable eruption sampling rate (ER) lead to results that must be interpreted with caution, since remaining patterns in the data may be attributable both to uncertainties in the correction as well as to real variability. When correcting global records, collected across regions that have been studied at different levels of detail, applying a universal correction to the whole dataset is likely to be too crude an approach to remove fully the influence of both spatial and temporal sampling variability.
In this section, we briefly illustrate how variations in ER, and in particular the relative sparseness of data from prehistoric times, severely constrains analyses of global eruption records. We aim to highlight the uncertainties that must be accounted for when interpreting global datasets.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Magnitude-related variation in eruption sampling rates
sections.text:
Globally, the number of known volcanic eruptions decreases through time. Although our global dataset excludes eruptions of VEI b 2, a very clear temporal sampling bias remains, and this bias is strongly magnitude dependent (Fig. 12B). Within the global eruption dataset, only the Siebert and Simkin (2002-) data includes eruption magnitudes. These records (Fig. 12B) show that known eruptions of VEI b 4 predominantly occurred within the past 500 years (91% of recorded VEI 2 eruptions are from 0 to 0.5 ka, and 98% from 0 to 5.5 ka). In contrast, the approximately straight trends in Fig. 12B suggest that the largest eruptions (VEI ≥ 5) have been sampled at a consistent ER. Nevertheless, the trend for these largest events steepens at b1 ka (32% of recorded VEI ≥ 5 eruptions are from 0 to 1 ka), suggesting that before this time a significant proportion of the largest eruptions remain unidentified. This agrees qualitatively with Deligne et al. (2010), who concluded that prior to 2 ka, only ~20% of eruptions of magnitude 6 are recorded, but that this rate of under-recording is statistically constant through the Holocene. This sampling rate may seem low, but more critically for a global analysis, it is also likely to be spatially variable (see Section 5.3).
The above result supports our approach in analysing regional-scale arc data, where we excluded events of volume b0.1 km3 (Fig. 2) in an
angmuir, 2009). The global dataset has been divided, following Huybers and Langmuir plot of Holocene eruptions (VEI ≥ 2; Siebert and Simkin, 2002-), separated according to
effort to achieve consistency in ER. Unfortunately, adopting a similar approach on a global scale renders the dataset too small for a comprehensive analysis, since it leaves some regions with virtually no data. Additionally, the Bryson et al. (2006) dataset, although likely to be dominated by larger eruptions, does not explicitly include any magnitude data. Thus, the global records in their entirety can only be analysed on the basis of eruption timing, but the very strong under-sampling of smaller eruptions (Fig. 12B) means that any such analysis must be interpreted with caution. The inclusion of magnitude data for the whole dataset would partly mitigate the temporal sampling bias, since estimates of volumetric or mass flux could be made.

sections.heading: 5.2.2. Correcting for temporal variation in eruption sampling rates
sections.text:
To interpret patterns within our global dataset, the temporal variation in ER must be corrected. To do this, we follow the method of Huybers and Langmuir (2009). The tested hypothesis is that volcanic activity in ice-covered regions increased after the LGM. If it is assumed that volcanism in ice-free regions proceeded at a constant rate (i.e. was not subject to any climatic forcing), then the ratio of activity in ice-covered (x) to ice-free (y) regions at any particular time reflects relative changes in the global rate of volcanic activity (Fig. 13A). Using this ratio corrects for temporal variability in ER if, and only if, the absolute value of ER at any one time is equal for ice-free and ice-covered regions (see Section 5.3). This is the critical assumption of the analysis.
Following Huybers and Langmuir (2009), we have applied a normalisation based on x/y to produce an eruption factor, Ef, which measures global eruption rate at any particular time relative to the most recent time bin (0–2 ka in the Huybers and Langmuir (2009) analysis; Fig. 13B):
Ef ¼ 1þ x=yð Þ= 1þ x0=y0ð Þ:
In this expression, x0 and y0 are the eruption frequencies in icecovered and ice-free areas, respectively, during the most recent time bin. For Ef > 1, this suggests increased volcanism in formerly ice-covered regions relative to recent times, assuming that rates of volcanism in ice-free regions were constant. If the full dataset is binned at 2 kyr intervals (Fig. 13A), the results suggest an increase in global volcanism at ca. 11 ka, decreasing after 7 ka (Fig. 13Bi). This was the original result of Huybers and Langmuir (2009; their Fig. 6B).

sections.heading: 5.2.3. Sensitivity of results to sampling variations
sections.text:
The method of analysing global eruption rates based on the ratio x/y means that Ef is highly sensitive to the denominator y, which is the number of eruptions in ice-free regions within any particular time bin. This value is extremely small across much of the global record. Thus, very minor changes to the dataset significantly affect the magnitude of Ef. For example, if the data are binned at 1 kyr (Fig. 13Bii) the amplitude and irregularity of the Ef curve dramatically increases.
Fig. 13A shows that recorded eruptions in the ice-free dataset averaged 4.35/kyr from 20 to 6 ka, before increasing. This equates to an exceedingly low sampling rate, as can be demonstrated by assuming that records of volcanism from the past 100 years are both complete and representative of the long-term eruption rate (excluding any climatic response). Thus, in ice-free areas, the 913 eruptions from A.D. 1904–2004 imply that ER from 20 to 6 ka was 0.05% (4.35/9130). That is, over a 14 kyr period, only 1 in 2000 eruptions of VEI ≥ 2 have been identified across ice-free regions. ER cannot be estimated for ice-covered regions, because the tested hypothesis postulates post-glacial changes in the absolute rate of volcanism for these areas, so different time periods cannot be compared. However, the general pattern for ice-covered regions shows an increase in recorded eruptions after 15 ka. This increase, and the consequent change in x/y
(Fig. 13Bi), was taken by Huybers and Langmuir (2009) to provide a quantitative measure of the global impact of deglaciation on volcanism. In reality, while the broad pattern in Fig. 13Bi may be real, the shape and amplitude of this curve strongly reflects the extremely low value of ER in ice-free regions.
The sensitivity of the analysis to small changes in the dataset can be shown by adjusting the assumed limit of glaciation. This is due to a few well-studied volcanoes dominating the records (i.e. a spatial, as well as a temporal sampling bias). The weight these volcanoes are given in the subsequent analysis does not necessarily reflect their long-term contribution to global volcanic output. For example, just four volcanoes (Aso, Etna, Asama, and Piton de la Fournaise), out of ~1500 Holocene subaerial volcanoes, account for 9.4% (483 eruptions) of the entire dataset. Additionally, the temporal distribution of records is clustered, and while this may partly reflect real episodic eruption patterns, it may also reflect the sections of individual volcanic stratigraphies that have been studied in detail. For example, during the 5–25 ka section of the record, the four best-represented volcanoes account for 13.7% (70 eruptions) of the dataset, but the specific centres are different (Chaîne des Puys, Gorely, Campi Flegrei and Mutnovsky; none of these are in the top 16 best-represented volcanoes for the entire 0–25 ka dataset). Although the well-studied volcanoes listed above are not directly on the border of our glaciation limit, others are. To illustrate the sensitivity to small changes in the defined limit of glaciation, we add data from two well-studied volcanoes (Orizaba, Mexico (32 eruptions); Sakura-jima, Japan (37 eruptions)) that lie immediately outside the ice-covered region, into the ice-covered records. Reanalysis of this amended dataset (2 kyr bins) suggests a large increase in Ef (Fig. 13Biii). This increase is due to the reduction in the denominator y: the amended dataset contains just two eruptions for the entire ice-free region from 10 to 12 ka (an estimated ER of 0.01%; coincident with the peak in Fig. 13Biii). In fact, Orizaba should, correctly, be placed in the ice-covered dataset, given its significant ice cover (e.g., White, 1986). However, we retain the originally defined ice limit for all other analyses in this paper.
Again, because of the sparse sampling rate, the global analysis is highly sensitive to the addition of a small number of new eruption records from ice-free regions. In Fig. 13Biv, 13 eruptions (b0.25% of the total dataset) from recent studies (Horz et al., 2004; Mehringer et al., 2005; Soto and Alvarado, 2006; Kutterolf et al., 2007; RodriguezGonzalez et al., 2009; Macías et al., 2010), dated between 5 and 11 ka and from ice-free regions, have been added to the global dataset (2 kyr bins). These alone significantly increase the number of records from ice-free regions during the early post-glacial period, resulting in a substantial reduction in the early-Holocene value of Ef. In contrast, adding 12 new dates (Watt et al., 2011b) between 5 and 11 ka from the ice-covered region (Fig. 13Bv) has only aminor effect on the original analytical results (Fig. 13Bi).
The purpose of the above analyses is not to produce a corrected or more accurate global dataset, but to demonstrate that the small size of the dataset (the low ER) across much of the post-glacial period prevents quantification of changes in global eruption rates. Strictly speaking, we cannot conclude that any one of the curves in Fig. 13B is more accurate than another. Importantly, we cannot be confident that the calculated Ef reflects real patterns, rather than spurious patterns arising from a spatially or temporally variable ER or an analytical assumption (such as the chosen limit of glaciation). Because the eruption rate in ice-covered regions is expected to have changed through time, it is simply not possible to compare values of ER precisely between ice-covered and ice-free regions. However, we suggest that ER is lower across the ice-free region as awhole, and discuss the basis for this assertion in more detail below (Section 5.3). The implication of more equal values of ER across the two regions would be to substantially reduce the amplitude of the Ef curve in Fig. 13Bi. What is clear from the above analyses is that if the absolute value of ER was both higher and more spatially consistent, then Ef would be considerably less sensitive to the
removal of data from one or two volcanoes, or the addition of a small number of new eruption data.

sections.heading: 5.3. Spatial sampling bias
sections.text: We have shown that although the global eruption dataset is large, the recording of eruptions is strongly skewed towards the lateHolocene, especially for eruptions of VEI b 4 (Figs. 12 and 13). Immediately after the LGM, eruption records are so sparse that the global data cannot easily be interpreted. Furthermore, our investigation suggests that eruption sampling rates (ER, indicating the proportion of known events), vary spatially. Although Huybers and Langmuir (2009) recognised that ER may vary between ice-covered and ice-free regions, the key assumption of their normalisation method is that they are equal. If they are unequal for any particular time period, then this would invalidate the global analysis. Evidence for spatial sampling bias must therefore be evaluated before a robust assessment of global eruption patterns can be made.

sections.heading: 5.3.1. Regional variation in ER
sections.text:
To investigate whether ER during the post-glacial period is not simply low, but also spatially variable, we have subdivided the ice-covered and ice-free regions into geographic sub-regions. We continue to use the original dataset and defined ice limit, and do not include any of the changes to the data discussed in Section 5.2.3. The proportional number of recorded eruptions during particular time periods, which provides an indication of relative changes in ER, is plotted for our defined sub-regions in Fig. 14. The resolution of this analysis has been deliberately limited in an effort to retain relatively large samples within each time bin.
Across ice-free regions, ER is spatially consistent between the 0–100 year records and the 0–1000 year records, but several subregions are strikingly under-represented prior to this. Indonesia, the Philippines, New Guinea to Tonga and the Indian Ocean account for over 60% of eruptions in ice-free regions over the past 1000 years. From 1 to 5 ka, the same locations account for b10% of the dataset. There is no known reason why the absolute rate of volcanism in these sub-regions should differ between these time periods; indeed,
the global analysis centres on the assumption that volcanism throughout these regions has not varied. Assuming that the past century is representative, ER for Indonesia, the countrywith themost historically active volcanoes (Simkin and Siebert, 2000), is 0.005% for the 5–20 ka period (for VEI ≥ 2). That is, for a period of ~15 kyr after the LGM, only 1 in 20,000 eruptions of VEI ≥ 2 has been identified in Indonesia. Fig. 14 suggests that ER varies by two orders of magnitude between different ice-free sub-regions, so that regions such as the Mediterranean, with sampling rates of >0.1%, come to dominate the 5–20 ka eruption record.
Similar data can be inspected for the ice-covered region. However, actual values of ER cannot be precisely estimated, since we expect some (unconstrained) post-glacial enhancement of volcanism relative to the present day, and the effect of this may vary between geographic regions, since we earlier concluded that the volcanic response to deglaciation was greater in non-arc settings than in arcs. In spite of this, ER appears to be far more spatially consistent through time than in ice-free regions (Fig. 14). The Andes sub-region shows some indication of relative under-sampling, but this pattern may also reflect real enhancement of volcanism in sub-regions incorporating non-arc volcanoes, such as continental Europe and Iceland.
The contrast between the relative spatial consistency in ER across ice-covered regions and the wide spatial variability for ice-free regions indicates a systematic spatial sampling bias. We suggest that the ice-free regions that are relatively well sampled (Ryukyu and S. Kyushu, Mediterranean, Pacific islands, Africa and Arabia, Atlantic islands, Antilles) are likely to have comparable ER to most ice-covered areas. For example, for the 5–20 ka period, these listed ice-free regions have an overall sampling rate of 0.20% (based again on assumed completeness
of the 0–100 year records). For the same period, ER for the entire global dataset is b0.17%, and the apparent rate for the entire ice-covered region b0.28% (these are maxima, again because the true figure for ice-covered regions would be lower if there was any post-glacial enhancement of volcanism). We therefore suggest that ER is at least of the same order of magnitude (i.e. ~0.2%) between the ice-covered regions and the well-sampled (as listed above) ice-free regions. In contrast, ER for ice-free regions such as Indonesia and the Philippines is as low as 0.005%. Any global analysis is invalid if it does not attempt to account for this.
It is not surprising that accessible, continental and developed regions have been more comprehensively studied than less-developed island nations. This difference is clear simply from the relative number of cited data sources between different parts of the world in the Bryson et al. (2006) database. Such variation is particularly significant for our analysis, since the well-studied regions were predominantly ice-covered (e.g., North America, Europe, Japan), while many of the ice-free sub-regions are developing island nations, commonly with difficult access and poor exposure for field studies (e.g., Indonesia, Philippines, Pacific arcs).

sections.heading: 5.3.2. Resolving variation between different volcano-tectonic settings
sections.text:
Our results from individual arcs led us to suggest that the impact of deglaciation on arc volcanism was smaller than that in non-arc settings. However, arcs account for the majority of subaerial volcanic eruptions. If the change in global volcanic flux was as large as implied by Huybers and Langmuir (2009), we may expect glaciated volcanic arcs to have played a role in this increase. It is worth examining the global dataset to see if it can be used to resolve the relative global
contribution of arcs to post-glacial eruption increases. To do this, we reject all non-arc records from the global dataset. In this amended dataset, southern Chile, the Cascades and Kamchatka account for 28% of eruption records. In these areas, we have already demonstrated that evidence of a post-glacial increase in volcanism is limited. Of the remaining ice-covered arcs, Japan is particularly well represented, accounting for 29% of eruptions.
Fig. 15 shows an identical analysis to that in Fig. 13, based on the arc-only global dataset. The dataset contains 4624 records, accounting for 86% of the entire global dataset. This 86% contrasts with the 90% contribution of arc volcanoes to eruption records since A.D. 1900 (Siebert and Simkin, 2002-). The difference in the non-arc proportion of the global records, from 10% since A.D. 1900 to 14% for 0–25 ka, may reflect real post-glacial changes in volcanic activity, but is far from sufficient to explain the magnitude of post-glacial enhancement suggested by Huybers and Langmuir (2009). This is confirmed by Fig. 15. Indeed, the patterns in Figs. 13 and 15 are virtually identical in terms of amplitude. This may lead us to conclude that the increase in arc volcanic output was indeed substantial, and similar

to that in non-arc settings. Was this pattern somehow missed within our individual analyses of the Chile, Cascade and Kamchatka arcs, or were these particular arcs for some reason less affected by ice retreat? The latter seems unlikely, since southern Chile contains more volcanoes affected by thick ice sheets than any other arc, and several volcanoes in the Cascades and Kamchatka were similarly affected (Section 2.1). Alternatively, perhaps the fact that our individual arc analyses were limited to large eruptions obscured any patterns. Again, if eruption frequency really increased to the extent suggested by Fig. 15, this seems unlikely. Indeed, most of the prehistoric records in the global dataset are based on dated tephra deposits, with 43% of records from 2 to 11.8 ka having volumes >0.1 km3 (based on the Siebert and Simkin (2002-) data). Thus, the types of record that make up the global dataset are comparable to those used in our analyses of individual arc segments (Figs. 10 and 11).
We suggest that the apparent contrast between our individual arc analyses and the global-scale patterns in Fig. 15 to a large extent reflects spatial sampling biases in the global dataset. If this is the case, and as argued in Sections 5.2.3 and 5.3.1, the amplitude of the peaks

Although regional studies (e.g., Maclennan et al., 2002; Nowell et al., 2006) have shown that a real increase in volcanism occurred after the LGM in non-arc volcanotectonic settings, this pattern cannot be easily disentangled from a global dataset that is strongly affected by spatially variable and, in general, extremely low sampling rates.

sections.heading: 5.3.3. Correcting for a spatial sampling bias
sections.text:
To demonstrate the impact of spatial variability in ER, we undertake a simple correction of the dataset from ice-free regions, using records from sub-regions that are relatively well sampled prior to 1 ka (Ryukyu and S. Kyushu, Mediterranean, Pacific islands, Africa and Arabia, Atlantic islands, Antilles; Fig. 14). We then scale these data to produce a measure for the entire ice-free region, using the proportional contribution from these well-sampled regions over the 0–100 yr period of the record. For example, if n eruptions are recorded from the well-sampled sub-regions in any 2 kyr time bin, and these same sub-regions account for x% of the records in the 0–100 yr period, then the corrected count for that same time bin is n / (x / 100). Given the extremely low overall value of ER, this is a crude correction. It also involves the assumption that the sub-regions used for the correction have an equal ER to ice-covered regions (which is not directly testable; see Section 5.3.1). However, a more complex approach cannot be justified, and this method at least allows a semi-quantitative assessment of changes in global rates of volcanic activity.
Spatially corrected results, using two different corrections based on combinations of the above sub-regions, are shown in Figs. 13C (for the entire global dataset) and 15C (for the arc-only global dataset). The two curves have similar peak amplitudes. The data in Fig. 13C indicate a post-glacial increase in global eruption rates by a factor of two, but this compares to a peak Ef value of seven in the equivalent spatially-uncorrected analysis of Huybers and Langmuir (2009) (their Figure 6C). The shape of the spatially-corrected curves supports the hypothesis of a pulse in volcanism of finite length, with an eruption factor close to one at >14 ka and b5 ka. This is expected if deglaciation only temporarily perturbs volcanic systems, such that at later times (b5 ka) the ratio of activity between ice-covered and ice-free regions is constant. We would not expect this ratio to be necessarily the same prior to the perturbation (>14 ka), when volcanic activity could be suppressed in ice-covered regions relative to the present day. However, the data coverage is too sparse to accurately test this.
It is notable that the spatially-corrected data in Fig. 15C (arc-only data) is again virtually identical to that in Fig. 13C. The two are not directly comparable, because the correction for the arc data is based on a smaller number of records (the correcting sub-regions in Fig. 13C include non-arc settings), but the results are essentially the same. Again, this appears to conflict with our conclusions from individual arcs. If there was an approximate doubling in the global frequency of arc eruptions for several thousand years, accounted for by activity in glaciated arcs, then this should be prominent in the records from southern Chile, the Cascades and Kamchatka. Data from Chile and Kamchatka do support some increase in eruption frequency during the early Holocene, but it was not as prominent as the global analysis suggests. We suggest that the apparent discrepancy between our individual-arc and global-arc analyses highlights the flawed nature of the global analysis, which is still strongly affected by a low overall ER. The crude nature of our spatial correction is clear from the irregularity of the ice-free curves in Figs. 13D and 15D. This irregularity in the denominator, y, is mirrored in Figs. 13C and 15C, where the apparent peaks in global eruption rate correspond to dips in the ice-free records, rather than to noticeable spikes in the ice-covered eruption records. In an ideal dataset (i.e. one sufficiently large to make a reliable correction for spatial sampling bias), the ice-free records would define a flat line in Figs. 13D and 15D over the 25–5 ka period, before better sampling rates begin to skew the data.
Thus, although the corrected curves still suggest a potential doubling of post-glacial global eruption rates (Figs. 13C and 15C), we reiterate that this should be treated cautiously, and may substantially exaggerate the true pattern. Furthermore, a more conservative estimate of the area over which ice-loading influenced volcanism would also reduce the amplitude of the peaks in Figs. 13C and 15C (cf. Huybers and Langmuir, 2009).
Ice-core records provide some independent evidence against which to test the timing of any post-glacial increase in global volcanic output. The age of a post-glacial cluster of sulphate peaks in Greenland ice cores (Zielinski, 2000) approximately matches that of the peak in our corrected global eruption curve (Fig. 13D). The same ice core data are also consistent with our suggestion that much of the increase in global volcanism was restricted to particular glaciated regions. There is no corresponding sulphate peak in Antarctic ice cores (Castellano et al., 2004; Kurbatov et al., 2006), where sulphate records show amore ambiguous pattern (cf. Narcisi et al., 2010), and the Greenland sulphate may predominantly be due to the well-documented enhancement of Icelandic volcanism (Maclennan et al., 2002), rather than reflecting globally widespread increases in activity.

sections.heading: 5.4. The timing and impact of post-glacial changes in global volcanism
sections.text:
The peak increase in global volcanism implied by the results in Fig. 13 lags the onset of deglaciation (19–20 ka in the Northern Hemisphere; Clark et al., 2009) by several thousand years. As discussed in Section 3.4.1, such lags may reflect the response times of various magmatic processes, and on a global scale are complicated by asynchrony in the timing and rate of ice retreat, acting across a wide range of different volcanic settings (cf. Tuffen, 2010).
During the second half of the deglaciation period (13–7 ka), increased CO2 emissions from enhanced volcanismmay have contributed to continuing climatic changes. Based on our spatially corrected global curves, as well as our regional-scale arc results, we tentatively suggest that global volcanic output increased by a factor of b2, and potentially much less. The volcanic contribution to atmospheric CO2 during the 13–7 ka period was therefore at the bottom end of the 15–70 ppm range postulated by Huybers and Langmuir (2009), if not lower. The size of this CO2 contribution may also have been overestimated, since it was based on a scaling of recent gas fluxes dominated by arc volcanic measurements. If non-arc settings account for a significant proportion of post-glacially enhanced volcanism (Maclennan et al., 2002; Nowell et al., 2006), then the generally lower carbon content of these magmas (Marty and Tolstikhin, 1998; Wallace, 2005) may have reduced the overall impact on atmospheric CO2 levels.
Our results agree well with the climate models of Roth and Joos (2012), who showed that proxy-based changes in carbon between the LGM and post-glacial period are inconsistent with both the timing and magnitude of the increase in volcanism postulated by Huybers and Langmuir (2009). However, the smaller increase in global volcanism suggested by our corrected data is potentially consistent with climate models (Roth and Joos, 2012). Our results indicate that volcanic emissions cannot have played a dominant role in regulating atmospheric CO2 after the LGM. Nevertheless, an increase in global volcanism by a factor of b2, lasting for a few millennia, could still have been an important source of CO2 emissions during the latter stages of deglaciation.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
The post-glacial explosive eruption history of glaciated arc segments, based on records of large eruptions, suggests that regionalscale ice retreat after the LGM led to a limited increase in volcanism. In the southernmost part of the Andean SVZ (southern Chile), explosive eruption frequency was approximately double that of the
mid-Holocene, for an ~3 kyr period beginning ~2 kyr after the final retreat of low-altitude ice. Further north, where the LGM ice sheet was narrower, such a pattern is less evident, but the same time period coincides with a doubling of explosive volumetric flux across the arc, accounted for by a few very large eruptions from the region's most active volcanoes. This pattern is consistent with a model whereby pooled melt, stored in the crust during glaciation, was released upon deglaciation due to increased magmatic overpressure and upper-crustal stress conditions more conducive to dyke formation. There is no requirement to invoke substantially increased post-glacial melt production.
In Kamchatka, explosive eruption frequency is also relatively reduced in the mid-Holocene relative to the early Holocene, but whether this pattern reflects the influence of ice retreat is ambiguous. In the Cascades, where the degree of ice unloading was the smallest of our studied arcs, the rate of volcanism throughout the post-glacial period shows little variation. Taken together, the three arcs do not show a statistically significant change in eruption frequency or magnitude that can be attributed to deglaciation. Our analyses are limited by the small size of available eruption datasets, but suggest that the impact of deglaciation was greatest in arcs that experienced the most ice unloading. However, this impact was far smaller than that in non-arc settings such as Iceland, which saw eruption frequencies increase by up to an order of magnitude.
The lack of eruption data from the last glacial period, and a general paucity of data for small-volume and effusive eruptions, hinder analyses of regional-scale eruption records. Our records of large-volume eruptions are subject to limited variability in temporal or magnituderelated sampling rates, but at the expense of providing only small datasets. To further understand the relationship between ice loading, magma storage and volcanic eruptions, there is a need for detailed case studies of currently- and formerly-glaciated volcanoes, and for improved eruption records in several poorly-studied parts of the world.
In an effort to constrain the contribution of arc volcanism to globalscale changes in post-glacial volcanic eruption rates, we reassess an existing global eruption dataset (VEI ≥ 2), compiled by Huybers and Langmuir (2009). Using this dataset, Huybers and Langmuir (2009) estimated amaximum seven-fold increase in post-glacial global volcanic activity. By critically examining spatial and temporal sampling biases, the peak in our equivalent curve suggests that eruption rate increased by a factor of two, but that this may still be a significant overestimate.
The rate of eruption recording over the past 25 kyr is stronglymagnitude dependent. The identification of eruptions with VEI ≥ 5 is temporally consistent before ~1 ka. In contrast, 98% of recorded Holocene VEI 2 eruptions are younger than 5.5 ka. Based on a comparison with records from the past 100 years, the sampling rate (i.e. proportion of identified eruptions, VEI ≥ 2) in the global dataset from 5 to 20 ka is b0.17%. However, this sampling rate varies by two orders of magnitude between different geographic regions. In some areas that were unglaciated, such as Indonesia, the sampling rate is as low as 0.005%: just 1 in 20,000 eruptions (VEI ≥ 2) have been identified. Since 20 ka, the spatial coverage of eruption records from formerlyglaciated regions is relatively more comprehensive. These regions are commonly in accessible, continental and developed locations, which has led to a higher eruption recording rate than in many tropical areas unaffected by glaciation. It is this spatial variability that exaggerates the apparent post-glacial increase in volcanism, and prevents precise quantification of the true pattern. Spatial sampling biases cannot be fully removed, and these obscure and overprint real global-scale changes in eruption frequency. It will not be possible to constrain global-scale patterns in volcanism to any greater degree of precision without substantially increased and more spatially consistent eruption records. Preservation and exposure, in addition to temporal and spatial sampling variability, must also be considered when interpreting past volcanic records on regional or global scales.
Our regional-scale results from volcanic arcs and our reassessment of global records suggest that volcanism cannot have formed the dominant contribution to increases in global atmospheric CO2 at any stage during the late-glacial and early Holocene. Nevertheless, volcanic output did increase on a global scale, forming an important CO2 source during the late post-glacial period. A substantial proportion of this output was due to strongly enhanced volcanism in non-arc settings, rather than being evenly distributed across all formerlyglaciated volcanoes.
